pr_title: feat(broker): FEEL expressions for message names

timeline.bodyText:
What happens if the message name expression evaluation fails?
If an incident is created then no other action should be applied to the workflow instance (e.g. don't open other subscriptions, don't go to ELEMENT_ACTIVATED state)
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
I don't get it.
Which line is opening another subscription? Which line goes to ELEMENT_ACTIVATED state?
My assumption was that the lines above have no side effects, and the only lines with side effects are wrapped in the lambda. Which only executes when the evaluation succeeded.
What am I missing?
replies.author: pihme

replies.bodyText: Maybe I've figured out what you mean. Please check again.
replies.author: pihme

timeline.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: Why do we evaluate every static message name expression in the transformer?
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
yeah, I thought you would stumble over this. To be honest, I grew less and less fond of it myself.
I implemented this bit in the very beginning. Back then I wanted to defer the start event handling to a different issue, like you eluded to.
My intention was to make sure that all BPMN models that worked before, would still work. And since all BPMN models so far use static value here, they are now evaluated in the transformer.
This was before I found StartEventTransformer. I think with StartEventTransofrmer and CatchEventBehavior both evaluating expressions, I might have covered all bases. But since I am unsure these are truly all cases where evaluation needs to take place, I left it in as a conservative coding measure.
replies.author: pihme

timeline.author: saig0
saig0

timeline.bodyText:
I think that adding a name to the message is not in the intent of this test case ;)
The idea was that a message without a name is invalid. But if the message is not used in the workflow (this can happen using the modeler) then it is ignored.
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
Well, we are now stricter than that.
        ZeebeExpressionValidator.verifyThat(Message.class)
            .hasValidExpression(
                Message::getName,
                expression -> expression.isConstantWithResultType(ResultType.STRING).isMandatory())

Not sure if I could figure out whether a message is used or not at this point. Or if the constraint in the runtime expression should be relaxed. Or if we cannot support this use case any longer.
replies.author: pihme

replies.bodyText:
On second thought, I added that constraint. And I guess I wanted to put it on a start event.
But what about ordinary messages? Shouldn't the name be mandatory? I'm a little confused here.
replies.author: pihme
